title: How Muslims Keep Fast in Ramadan

content.heading: 1. The Purpose and Meaning of Fasting in Islam
text: Ramadan fasting is a command of God, as it is said in the Quran.
"You who have believed. Worship is ordained on you in the way that it was ordained on those before you so that perhaps you might remain mindful." (Quran 2:183)
The main goals of fasting are:

list: Building self-control and willpower.
Building a stronger relationship with Allah.
Practicing gratitude through the hardships of the poor.
Cleansing the body and soul through fasting from food, liquids, and sinful acts.

content.heading: 2. Ramadan Fasting: The Basics
text: Ramadan fasting means staying away from food and drink, cigarettes, and sex from dawn (Fajr) to dusk (Maghrib) — not just physical renunciation but also renouncing misdeeds such as lying, backbiting, anger, and gossip.
The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) related:
"Whosoever does not leave off false speech (i.e., lying), and evil deeds, and cursing individuals, Allah does not need him to leave off his food and drink." (Bukhari)
There are two major phases of fasting in Islam:

list: Suhoor (Pre-Dawn Meal): A light nutritious meal consumed before the morning prayer.
Iftar (Breaking of the Fast): An evening meal traditionally opened with dates and water, followed by a wholesome meal.

content.heading: 3. Who Should Fast?
text: It is obligatory upon all adult Muslim men and women who have normal physical and mental health to observe fasting. It is, however, exempt for those experiencing sincere hardships, namely:

list: Children (under puberty)
The elderly (who are weak and may not be able to bear the fast)
Nursing women and pregnant females (if fasting may adversely affect their health or the fetus)
Sick people (with medical issues that make fasting difficult)
Travelers (embarking on long journeys)
Women on menstruation or Nifas (they will have to catch up on missed fasts later)

text: Those unable to fast due to continuous illness or extreme old age can compensate by giving food to a poor person for every missed fast (Fidya).

content.heading: 4. Suhoor for Fasting: Importance of Pre-Fasting Breakfast
text: Suhoor is of prime importance since it keeps one going throughout the day. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) explained:
"Eat Suhoor, as it definitely holds a blessing." (Sahih Bukhari & Muslim)
A healthy Suhoor consists of:

list: Complex carbohydrates (e.g., oats, whole-grain bread, brown rice)
Proteins (e.g., eggs, yogurt, cheese, nuts)
Fresh fruits and vegetables loaded with vitamins and water
Regardless, one must have enough water intake to avoid dehydration during the day.

content.heading: 5. Breaking the Fast: Sunnah of Iftar
text: At sunset, Muslims break their fasting according to the Sunnah of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH):
"When one of you breaks his fast, let him break it with dates, for they are blessed. If he does not have dates, then with water, for it is pure." (Abu Dawood)
A healthy Iftar should consist of:

list: Dates and water to replenish energy and hydration.
Lean protein and vegetables for a balanced diet.
Avoiding fried and highly processed foods to avoid sluggishness.

content.heading: 6. Acts of Worship with Fasting
text: Fasting in Ramadan is not just an absence of food; it is also an opportunity to ramp up worship. Other acts performed during fasting include:
Living in the Quran: Ramadan is the month during which the Quran was revealed, so it is a special moment for reflection and study.

list: Extra Salah: Taraweeh prayers attract very big spiritual prizes and are offered at night.
Charity: Ramadan is an important time for increasing acts of charity and helping the poor.
Asking for forgiveness and making du'a: Muslims seek Allah's mercy through very heart-touching supplications, particularly during the last 10 nights.

content.heading: 7. Common Problems and How to Deal with Them
text: Fasting can incite physical and mental problems. Staying ready and disciplined can make fasting challenges less hectic. Some common issues are as follows:

list: Dehydration: Drinking lots of water during normal times is important.
Fatigue and Low Energy: Proper rest and balanced food help.
Cravings: Reminding oneself of the spiritual rewards of fasting helps in resisting temptations.
Work and Study Balance: Planning the day well according to prayer and fasting schedules ensures productivity.

content.heading: 8. The Last Ten Nights and Laylatul Qadr
text: The last ten nights of Ramadan are those that have the most spiritual significance, as they harbor within them Laylatul Qadr, a night better than a thousand months (Quran 97:3). These are the nights during which Muslims engage themselves the most in prayers, recitation of the Quran, and requests for forgiveness.
The Prophet (PBUH) made me confident in locating Laylatul Qadr on odd nights of the remaining ten days.

content.heading: 9. Ending Ramadan: Eid al-Fitr Celebration
text: Eid al-Fitr is celebrated at the end of Ramadan with a special prayer. Collective charity referred to as Zakat al-fitr is where people participate. It also serves as a reason for the family reunion. It expresses a point of thanks for the weaknesses involved in upholding the fast and a celebration of the blessings of Ramadan.

content.heading: 8. The Last Ten Nights and Laylatul Qadr
text: The last ten nights of Ramadan are those that have the most spiritual significance, as they harbor within them Laylatul Qadr, a night better than a thousand months (Quran 97:3). These are the nights during which Muslims engage themselves the most in prayers, recitation of the Quran, and requests for forgiveness.
The Prophet (PBUH) made me confident in locating Laylatul Qadr on odd nights of the remaining ten days.

content.heading: Conclusion
text: Fasting during Ramadan is a very spiritual experience that deepens faith, develops discipline, and promotes the feeling of unity among Muslims. Through Islamic regulation of fasting, suhoor, iftar, and acts of worship, Muslims are able to reap all the benefits from this holy month.For those looking for in-depth guidance, My Mufti App download is a must-have, offering fasting timetables, Duas, Quran study timetables, and expert tips to maximize Ramadan.

title: What are the Five Pillars of Islam?

content.heading: Introduction
text: To live a complete life is to have regulations for each aspect of man's life. The religion itself is based on five acts of worship known as the Five Pillars of Islam. These pillars are the foundation of the Muslim faith and practice, providing it with structure and discipline so that one can be near Allah.
It is not until Allah's servants, be they believers or unbelievers, acquire this knowledge of the pillars that they can enjoy the marvelous teaching thereof.

For all those interested in knowing genuine Islamic wisdom and advice, sources such as My Mufti App become of great use for intellectual insight into Islamic philosophy. With the application of wise advice and scholar-provided comments, individuals get empowered in the context of knowledge development about Islam. And now let us know more deeply about the Five Pillars of Islam.

content.heading: 1. Shahada (Faith and Testimony)
text: The Shahada is the first and most basic pillar of Islam and is the proclamation of faith. It reads:
"La ilaha illallah, Muhammadur Rasulullah."
This is a translation of: "There is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is His Messenger."
This declaration confirms the monotheistic faith in a single God (Allah) and accepts Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as the last messenger.
The Shahada is not merely a verbal confirmation but an affirmation of living by Islamic teachings. It is the total submission to Allah and marks the gateway into the Islamic religion.

content.heading: 2. Salah (Prayer)
text: The second is Salah, or the five prayers performed daily. Muslims pray at the following times during the day:

list: Fajr (before dawn)
Dhuhr (noon)
Asr (afternoon)
Maghrib (sunset)
Isha (night)

text: Prayer is an immediate form of communication between Allah and a believer. It induces discipline, mindfulness, and closeness to God.
Every prayer has certain recitations, actions, and supplications. My Mufti App can guide Muslims in the proper manner to offer Salah, making their prayers in accordance with true Islamic guidelines.

For those who wish to deepen their belief and acquire authentic Islamic knowledge, My Mufti App is an asset. It offers expert advice, educational resources, and practical tools to aid each and every phase of a Muslim's religious life.

content.heading: 3. Zakat (Charity and Almsgiving)
text: Zakat is the third pillar of Islam and focuses on economic justice and social responsibility.
Zakat obliges financially capable Muslims to contribute 2.5% of their yearly savings to the poor so that wealth can be distributed and the poor are taken care of.
The advantages of Zakat are:

list: Cleaning one's wealth
Helping the poor and downtrodden
Lessening economic inequality

text: Zakat differs from voluntary charity (Sadaqah) since it is compulsory.
Most Muslims use online resources, such as My Mufti App, to compute and pay Zakat in the right manner so that it can reach needy individuals.

content.heading: 4. Sawm (Fasting during Ramadan)
text: The fourth pillar is Sawm, or fasting, during the month of Ramadan. Muslim people abstain from food, drink, smoking, and sex from sunrise to sunset as a sign of worship and self-control.
The fast is broken every day at sundown with the Iftar meal, and the morning meal is Suhoor.
Fasting promotes compassion for the needy, increases self-discipline, and enhances religious awareness.
Besides physical abstinence, it is a period for more worship, prayer, and recitation of the Quran.
For the inexperienced or in need of instruction on correct observance, My Mufti App provides instructional materials and reminders to ensure spiritual direction throughout Ramadan.

content.heading: 5. Hajj (Pilgrimage to Mecca)
text: The fifth pillar is Hajj, the holy pilgrimage to Mecca.
It is mandatory for all financially and physically able Muslims to make at least once in their lifetime.
Hajj takes place once a year in the Islamic month of Dhul-Hijjah and is made up of a set of religious rituals that signify unity, humility, and obedience to Allah.
Major rituals of Hajj are:

list: Tawaf (rounding the Kaaba seven times)
Sa'i (walking back and forth between hills Safa and Marwah)
Standing at Arafat (the peak of Hajj)
Mina and the symbolic devil stoning

text: Hajj brings together Muslims worldwide, binding them in the idea of equality before Allah.
With the intricacies involved in the pilgrimage, My Mufti App provides assistance as a useful guide, providing step-by-step information on how to carry out Hajj properly.

Through the pillars, Muslims keep a systematic relationship with Allah and adherence to righteousness.

content.heading: What is Halal Food?
text: Food is one of the fundamental aspects of life, and for Muslims, it is essential that the food they consume aligns with Islamic principles. Halal food refers to food that is permissible for Muslims to eat under Islamic law, as outlined in the Quran and the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It is not limited to just meat; halal encompasses all food and drinks that are in accordance with Islamic guidelines, including purity, hygiene, and ethical sourcing.

list: Dehydration: Drinking lots of water during normal times is important.
Fatigue and Low Energy: Proper rest and balanced food help.
Cravings: Reminding oneself of the spiritual rewards of fasting helps in resisting temptations.
Work and Study Balance: Planning the day well according to prayer and fasting schedules ensures productivity.

content.heading: 1. Understanding the Idea of Halal
text: The term "Halal" is an Arabic word meaning "permitted" or "lawful." It applies to every aspect of a Muslim’s life, including food, finances, clothing, and behavior. In contrast, "Haram" refers to things that are forbidden. When discussing food, Halal refers to anything that complies with Islamic teachings, while Haram refers to anything clearly forbidden.
O you who have believed, eat from the good things which We have provided for you and be grateful to Allah if it is [indeed] Him that you worship. (Quran 2:172)

content.heading: 2. Halal Meat and Slaughtering Process (Zabiha)
text: In order for the meat to be Halal, it should originate from an allowed animal and be slaughtered according to Islamic law. The method, referred to as Zabiha, needs certain conditions to be fulfilled:

list: The Animal Has to Be Halal: Islam allows the intake of animals like cows, sheep, goats, chickens, and camels. Animals like pigs and carnivorous hunters are forbidden.

The Slaughtering Must Be Done by a Sane, Adult Muslim: The animal being slaughtered should be slaughtered by a sane person who is an adult and recites Bismillah (In the name of Allah) and Allahu Akbar (Allah is the Greatest) before cutting it.

The Blood Must Be Drained: The jugular veins and carotid artery need to be cut quickly with a sharp knife to facilitate quick and humane slaughter. The blood needs to be completely drained from the carcass since eating blood is forbidden in Islam.

No Stunning or Cruelty: Islam promotes the humane treatment of animals. The slaughtering process should be designed to cause as little suffering as possible, and gratuitous cruelty is absolutely prohibited.

content.heading: 3. Ingredients that are Halal and Haram in Foods
text: Aside from meat, many foods have ingredients that need to be scrutinized to determine if they are Halal or Haram. Some of the common categories include:

list: Halal Ingredients: Vegetables, fruits, grains, nuts, and legumes; Dairy products (as long as they do not contain animal-based enzymes from Haram sources); Seafood; Vegetable oils and fats.

Haram Ingredients: Alcohol and intoxicants; Pork and pork-derived products (including gelatin, lard, and emulsifiers); Enzymes and rennet from non-Halal sources; Cross-contamination from non-Halal items.

content.heading: 4. Halal Food Labels and Certification
text: Many food products today carry Halal certification, which means they have been verified by a reputable Islamic authority. Some prominent Halal certification agencies include:

list: Halal Monitoring Committee (HMC) – UK
Islamic Food and Nutrition Council of America (IFANCA) – USA
JAKIM – Malaysia
Majelis Ulama Indonesia (MUI) – Indonesia

content.heading: 5. The Global Halal Food Market
text: Halal food demand has grown substantially, driven by the increasing Muslim population and ethical food-conscious consumers. The global Halal food market is now worth over $2 trillion and continues to expand into mainstream markets.

content.heading: 6. The Ethical and Health Value of Halal Food
text: Beyond its religious significance, Halal food is associated with various ethical and health benefits:

list: Cleanliness and hygiene: Islam emphasizes cleanliness in food preparation.
Humane treatment of animals: The Halal slaughter process reduces suffering.
Elimination of harmful additives: Halal food is free from intoxicants and harmful ingredients.

content.heading: 7. Difficulty in Recognizing Halal Food
text: Although the Halal market is growing, there are challenges:

list: Mislabeling: Some Halal foods do not have proper certification.
Hidden Haram ingredients: Certain flavor enhancers, preservatives, and additives may contain Haram components.
Cross-contamination: Common kitchen tools may cause cross-contamination with non-Halal foods.

content.heading: Conclusion
text: Halal food plays a crucial role in a Muslim’s lifestyle, ensuring that dietary laws are followed while promoting ethical and hygienic food practices. From Halal meat processing to recognizing permissible ingredients, it is vital to know what constitutes Halal food.

title: What Does Islam Teach About Charity?

text: Charity holds a central place in Islam. It is not merely a good deed, but a divine obligation that reflects a Muslim’s faith, compassion, and sense of responsibility. Islam emphasizes charity as a means of purifying wealth, reducing economic disparities, and fostering unity among people.

In today’s digital world, apps like My Mufti App have made it easier for Muslims to fulfill their charitable duties. From Zakat calculators to guidance on Sadaqah, My Mufti App empowers believers with practical tools to navigate their religious obligations.

content.heading: The Concept of Charity in Islam
text: Islam teaches that everything belongs to Allah, and humans are only trustees. Giving to the less fortunate is both an act of obedience and a means to uplift society. Charity comes in many forms: financial aid, feeding others, supporting orphans, or even offering a kind word or smile.

"The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed of grain that sprouts seven ears; in every ear, there are a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies (reward) for whom He wills." (Quran 2:261)
1. Zakat – The Obligatory Charity
Zakat is a pillar of Islam and a mandatory act for financially capable Muslims. It requires donating 2.5% of savings annually to specific beneficiaries:
"Zakat expenditures are only for the poor and needy, and for those who collect it..." (Quran 9:60)
Its purpose is to purify wealth and promote economic balance. The My Mufti App (https://mymuftiapp.com/) provides a Zakat calculator and educational resources to simplify this obligation.
2. Sadaqah – The Voluntary Charity
Sadaqah refers to voluntary charity. There are no specific conditions, amounts, or restrictions on who can receive it. It may include money, food, clothes, or acts of kindness.
The Prophet ﷺ said:
"Charity does not reduce wealth." (Sahih Muslim)
3. Sadaqah Jariyah – Ongoing Charity
This is a form of charity that continues to benefit others long after the giver’s death. Examples include:
list: Building a mosque or school
Donating books or religious material
Providing clean water

text: The Prophet ﷺ said:
"When a person dies, their deeds end except for three: continuous charity, beneficial knowledge, or a righteous child who prays for them." (Sahih Muslim)

content.heading: Benefits of Charity
text: Charity in Islam yields spiritual and worldly benefits:
list: Purifies the soul from greed and attachment
Brings barakah (blessings) and multiplies wealth
Acts as a shield against hardships and trials
Leads to forgiveness of sins and divine reward

text: "Charity extinguishes sins just like water extinguishes fire." (Tirmidhi)

content.heading: Charity as a Social Responsibility
text: Charity is not just a personal virtue, but a collective duty. It nurtures a compassionate society, reduces poverty, and builds economic justice. Muslims are encouraged to give frequently and look for opportunities to help—be it local communities, educational causes, or global crises.

content.heading: Conclusion
text: Charity is a cornerstone of Islam—vital for spiritual growth, social equity, and community well-being. Through Zakat, Sadaqah, and Sadaqah Jariyah, Muslims are encouraged to share their blessings.
Tools like My Mufti App make fulfilling these obligations easier, ensuring our giving is meaningful, sincere, and aligned with Islamic values.

content.heading: 1. Early Life and Background
text: 570 of the Common Era is the year of birth of the Prophet Muhammad, in the city of Makkah (presently in Saudi Arabia). His father Abdullah died a few months before his birth, while his mother Amina died when he was six years old. From then, he was taken care of by his grandfather Abdul Muttalib, after whom he was delivered into the care of his uncle Abu Talib, who reared him as his own. Muhammad (PBUH), even as a child, was distinguished by three qualities: integrity, honesty, and generosity. Trading was there where he earned the name Al-Amin (The Trustworthy) owing to his truthfulness: a merchant, he married Khadijah, a wealthy wife and respected businesswoman, her foremost ally.

content.heading: 2. The First Revelation and the Call to Prophethood
text: While meditating in the Cave of Hira, from which he usually would look down on the valley of Makkah, Muhammad (Peace be upon Him) was 40 years old when Allah's first revelation through Jibreel (Gabriel) commanded him to READ (Quran 96:1). This was when the call to prophethood and the beginning of sharing the Divine message of the Holy Quran.
He initially preached Islam in secret to intimate family and friends. His message centered on:

list: The uniqueness of Allah (Tawheed)
The value of compassion and justice
The denouncement of idolatry and social injustices

content.heading: 3. Obstacles and Persecution at Makkah
text: The teachings of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) were refused by the Makkah authorities. Because they threatened their power and were relevant to their economic interests. The Companions of Prophet (PBUH) suffered severe torment, torture, and boycotts. Yet, he stood firm and urged his followers to demonstrate forbearance in the face of such enmity.

A few of the Muslim individuals escaped their native land and found asylum in Abyssinia (present-day Ethiopia) with the Christian king known as Negus. Later, the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and fellow Muslims were granted entry into Yathrib (later Madinah) after being converted into victims of long-term torture by the state. This is an episode called Hijrah, which reversed the course of the Islamic calendar.

content.heading: 4. Creating a Just Society in Madinah
text: When he arrived in Madinah, the Prophet (PBUH) set up an Islamic State where justice was performed, people were given their rights, and the state was one of equality. He drafted the Constitution of Madinah that:

list: Promoted religious coexistence of Muslims, Jews, and other nations.
Protected all the rights and obligations of citizens.
Established the rule of law and justice.

text: In Madinah, the great Islamic civilization blossomed, with the Prophet (PBUH) guiding that same community through some of the great wars of Islam during which they were allowed to choose their own freedom of worship, namely, Badr, Uhud, and Khandaq. He still cherished peace for peace's sake and only welcomed war as a last resort.

content.heading: 5. Conquest of Makkah and the Final Sermon
text: In 630 CE, after years of fighting came Muhammad along with his followers in a pacified atmosphere back to Makkah. Instead of seeking revenge on his enemies, he forgave them and left an example of justice and mercy for the world to see, one that was unmatched.
On that note, he gave his great Farewell Sermon on Mount Arafat, summarizing the key Islamic teachings:

list: Equality of all human beings regardless of race or social standing.
Sanctity of property and life.
Importance of women's rights and justice.
The pillars of justice and righteousness in society.

text: In 578 the year when the Prophet departed his life, al Bakhari was born. He was deeply mourned by his followers. Numerous questions are asked before you can establish whether they committed a crime or not.

title: Why is the Significance of Kaaba important?

content.heading: Introduction
text: The Kaaba or the House of Allah is Islam's holiest place. Situated at the center of Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, it is the target of Muslim prayers and the journey of millions of pilgrims each year. The Kaaba is of monumental religious, historic, and spiritual importance to all Muslims.

With advancements in technology improving religious knowledge, sites such as My Mufti App assist Muslims in learning more about the significance, history, and place of the Kaaba in Islamic practice. My Mufti App offers genuine resources, scholarly analysis, and advice on how to perform religious rituals surrounding the Kaaba.

content.heading: 1. The Historical Origins of the Kaaba
text: The Kaaba was built in the days of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham, peace be upon him) and Prophet Ismail (Ishmael, peace be upon him). They were commanded by Allah to build the Kaaba as the very first place of worship on Earth, as per Islamic history.

content.heading: 2. The Kaaba as Qibla (Direction of Prayer)
text: One of the deepest points about the Kaaba is that it is the Qibla, or the direction in which Muslims everywhere face when they pray. Muslims originally prayed facing Jerusalem, but then Allah instructed them to turn around and face the Kaaba. This shift is described in the Quran:

"We have indeed turned your face toward a direction of worship, [O Muhammad], toward heaven, and We will surely turn you to a Qibla with which you will be pleased. So turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] are, turn your faces toward it." (Quran 2:144)
This combined practice of prayer reflects Muslim solidarity, asserting the belief that the faithful worship a single God, irrespective of the location or culture.

content.heading: 3. The Kaaba and the Hajj Pilgrimage
text: The Kaaba is at the center of Hajj, the yearly pilgrimage that is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. Millions of Muslims make their way to Mecca each year to undertake Hajj, following the rituals instituted by Prophet Ibrahim and re-established by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

list: Tawaf: Pilgrims make seven counterclockwise circuits around the Kaaba, a gesture of devotion and submission to Allah.
Sa'i: Pilgrims move between the Safa and Marwa hills, recalling Hajar's (Hagar's) quest for water for her son, Ismail.
Standing at Arafat: Pilgrims congregate on Mount Arafat in a deep expression of worship and repentance.

content.heading: 4. The Kaaba and Umrah
text: The Kaaba is equally central to Umrah, the lesser pilgrimage that can be performed any time of the year. While Umrah is not obligatory, it holds great spiritual merit and includes similar rituals to Hajj:

list: Ihram: The sacred state of purification entered before approaching Mecca
Tawaf: Seven circumambulations around the Kaaba
Sa'i: Walking between Safa and Marwah seven times
Halq/Taqsir: Shaving or trimming hair upon completion

content.heading: 5. The Black Stone and Other Holy Features
text: The Kaaba contains several sacred elements, most notably:

list: Hajr al-Aswad (Black Stone): Set in the eastern corner, believed to have descended from Paradise
Maqam Ibrahim: The stone where Prophet Ibrahim stood during Kaaba's construction
Hijr Ismail: A semi-circular wall marking the original Kaaba boundaries
Kiswa: The ornate black cloth covering renewed annually

content.heading: 6. Symbolism and Spiritual Significance
text: The Kaaba embodies profound spiritual meanings:

list: Universal center of monotheistic worship
Symbol of unity in diversity for 1.8 billion Muslims
Physical manifestation of divine connection
Reminder of Prophet Ibrahim's legacy

content.heading: 7. Kaaba as a Unifying Agent of Muslims
text: The Kaaba transcends human divisions, creating unparalleled unity:
"Indeed, this nation of yours is one nation, and I am your Lord, so worship Me." (Quran 21:92)

list: Wear identical white garments (Ihram)
Chant the same supplications
Perform identical rituals
Face the same direction in prayer

content.heading: Conclusion
text: The Kaaba remains the spiritual heartbeat of Islam, connecting:

list: Historical legacy with modern practice
Earthly worship with cosmic order
Individual devotion with collective identity

text: For deeper exploration of Kaaba's significance and pilgrimage guidance, My Mufti App provides:

Ritual tutorials
Scholarly interpretations

title: What is the Difference between Sunni and Shia?

text: Islam is a religious faith, millions more than 1.9 billions today follow it around the world. It can generally be divided into two large groups: Sunni and Shia. Although both have the same elementary belief in the one God (Allah), in prophethood of Muhammad (peace be filtered over him), and Quranic holy scriptures, there are considerable differences between them in terms of leadership, religious practices, historical views, and theological meanings. The article in question is a comparative analysis of the major differences between Sunni Islam and Shia Islam, aimed at creating clarity on various shades of these two respective sects.

content.heading: Historical Background
text: The earliest historical split between Sunni and Shia resulted from a debate over the rightful heir of Prophet Muhammad (saw) following his death in 632. Protestants argue that succession must be determined through consent whereas Shia cite that all genuine leadership should emanate only from the Prophet's family, i.e. his cousin and son-in-law, Ali Ibn Abi Talib.

Sunni Perspective: Sunnis say that Abu Bakr, the Prophet's friend and in-law, was the rightful first caliph following the consensus of most companions of the Prophet. Sunnis trace the sola line through the first four caliphs as the "Rightly Guided Caliphs": Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali.

Shia Perspective: Shia believe that Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) had already nominated Ali as his rightful successor. Shia believe that the leadership must remain within the family of the Prophet, i.e., within the institution of Imamate, i.e., a succession of divinely appointed leaders beginning from Ali and going through his family.

content.heading: Religious Leadership and Authority
text: Of course, the Sunni-Shia divide is one of the reasons for consociational republicanism.

Sunni Islam: Sunnis lack a single religious authority. Religious affairs are instead directed by scholars, jurists, and religious institutions such as Egypt's Al-Azhar University. Sunnis place a very high premium on scholars' consensus (Ijma) and analogy (Qiyas) in interpreting religion.

Shia Islam: Shias believe in a hierarchical religious authority, where ayatollahs and grand ayatollahs play a central role. Shias believe in the Imams, divinely appointed infallible leaders, and are traced back to Ali and his progeny.

content.heading: Key Doctrinal Differences
text: Despite sharing the same faith in the Five Pillars of Islam—Shahada (faith), Salah (prayer), Zakat (charity), Sawm (fasting), and Hajj (pilgrimage)—variances occur with how some of the practices are done.

list: Sunnis offer five daily prayers: Fajr, Dhuhr, Asr, Maghrib, and Isha.
Shias tend to conjoin Dhuhr and Asr, and Maghrib and Isha, praying three times a day while still fulfilling the complete five prayers.
Their hand positioning also varies, with Sunnis folding their hands and Shias placing their hands on their sides.
Sunnis have observed the day of Asura (10th of Muharram) as the day of remembrance and fasting; after having escaped Pharaoh, Prophet Musa (Moses) had entered his people.

The Shia observances of Ashura are, nevertheless, regarded as mourning the martyrdom of Imam Hussein, the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)'s grandson, in the Karbala War. Mourning processions, recitals, and in some instances self-flagellating are just some of the activities to mourn their loss.

text: Hadith and Religious Scriptures

list: Almost fully on the collection of hadith, Sunni depend on the contributions of scholars like Muslim and Bukhari.
Shias prefer those hadiths which are narrated by the Prophet's family members and their companions and are included in works such as Al-Kafi.

content.heading: Differences in Religious Practice
text: Mut'ah (Temporary Marriage):

list: Temporary marriage (Mut'ah) is forbidden by Sunni Islam as a practice abrogated by the Prophet.
Mut'ah is permitted by Shia Islam under certain conditions as a valid contract with mutual agreement.

text: Call to Prayer (Adhan):

list: Sunni and Shia Muslims differ only slightly in the wording of the Adhan. Shias include "Ali is the Wali (friend) of Allah" in the call to prayer.

content.heading: Differences and Unity in Modern Perspective
text: Notwithstanding these differences, one would find that the Sunni and Shia share far more similarities than differences; belief in one God, the Quran, and the prophethood of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). In this respect, attempts at uniting Muslims around the world have been made by various Islamic scholars and institutions, including internet platforms like the My Mufti App, which aims to furnish authentic Islamic guidance for all Muslims regardless of sectarian affiliation.

content.heading: Conclusion
text: Shia and Sunni Islam ideologies have been divided mainly due to historical accounts, differences in theological understanding, and issues pertaining to political superiority. Although the differences have on occasion resulted in conflicts, both sects observe the same essential principles of Islam. Admiration of these differences with an open heart fosters respect and harmony among Muslims everywhere while maintaining the unity which Islam teaches. Regardless of sect, belief, righteousness, and obedience to Allah must be the focus.

title: What is the Role of Women in Islam?

text: Islam is a religion that values equality, respect, and justice for all people, regardless of gender. The role of women in Islam is one of immense importance, encompassing spiritual, social, economic, and political dimensions. While misconceptions persist about the status of women in Islam, the religion itself grants women rights and responsibilities that contribute to a balanced and just society. With the advancement of technology, platforms like My Mufti App have made it easier for individuals to access authentic Islamic knowledge about the rights and roles of women in Islam. Through expert guidance and scholarly insights, My Mufti App ensures that the true teachings of Islam regarding women’s roles are easily accessible.

content.heading: 1. Spiritual Equality and Role in Worship
text: In Islam, men and women are equal in their devotion to Allah and their pursuit of righteousness. Both are expected to fulfill their religious obligations, such as prayer, fasting, charity, and pilgrimage. The Quran explicitly states:

"Whoever does righteousness, whether male or female, while they are a believer—We will surely cause them to live a good life, and We will surely give them their reward according to the best of what they used to do." (Quran 16:97)

This verse highlights that both men and women have an equal opportunity to attain spiritual success. Women are encouraged to seek knowledge, engage in religious discussions, and contribute to Islamic scholarship. Many prominent female scholars, such as Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), played crucial roles in the preservation and transmission of Islamic teachings.

content.heading: 2. Education and Intellectual Contributions
text: Education is highly emphasized in Islam, and seeking knowledge is a duty for both men and women. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:
"Every Muslim is obligated to seek knowledge." (from Ibn Majah)

Historically, Muslim women have made significant contributions to education and scholarship. One of the earliest examples is Fatima al-Fihri, who founded the University of Al-Qarawiyyin in Morocco, the world’s oldest continuously operating university. Women have served as scholars, poets, and jurists throughout Islamic history, contributing to various fields of knowledge. Through My Mufti App, women can access Islamic educational resources, learn about their rights, and seek religious guidance from reputable scholars. This empowers them to practice their faith with confidence and clarity.

content.heading: 3. Family and Social Responsibilities
text: Women play an integral role in family life, serving as mothers, daughters, sisters, and wives. In Islam, the family unit is highly prized, and women are accorded respect within it. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) said:
"Paradise lies under the feet of mothers." (Ahmad, Nasai)

Motherhood is considered one of the noblest responsibilities, as it involves nurturing and educating future generations. Islam also emphasizes the importance of kindness and respect toward women. The Quran declares:
"And live with them in kindness. For if you dislike them—perhaps you dislike something in which Allah has placed much good." (Quran 4:19)

Women are not confined to the home; they have the right to engage in social and professional activities while maintaining a balance between their personal and communal roles. Islam encourages women to be active members of society, contributing to community welfare and social justice.

content.heading: 4. Economic Rights and Financial Independence
text: Islam provided women with financial rights more than 1,400 years ago, even before most contemporary societies acknowledged them. Women in Islam are entitled to:

list: Own and inherit property
Enter into business and trade
Retain their earnings without needing to share them with their husbands
Get financial assistance from their fathers or husbands, even if they possess personal wealth

text: The Quran states:
"For men is a share of what they have earned, and for women is a share of what they have earned." (Quran 4:32)

There have been numerous successful Muslim businesswomen throughout history. The most well-known example is that of Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, the Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) wife, who was a successful and dignified merchant. With contemporary technology, empowerment and financial literacy are within reach. My Mufti App is an example of guidance on Islamic finance that assists women in understanding their monetary rights and handling their wealth according to Islamic principles.

content.heading: 5. Political and Leadership Roles
text: Against false impressions, Islam does permit women to become leaders and rulers. Women have assumed crucial roles as politicians, army leaders, and administrators in the course of Islamic history. These include Shajarat al-Durr, an Egyptian ruler, and Amina of Zazzau, a strong leader in West Africa. The Quran refers to the leadership of Queen Bilqis (Queen of Sheba), a wise and governing queen. Women were consulted by the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) on significant issues and their opinions were respected. Women in the present age continue to make contributions towards social and political advancements in the Islamic context. My Mufti App is an online platform for women interested in knowing about their rights in leadership and governance.

content.heading: 6. Modesty and Women's Dress Code
text: Modesty is an important part of Islamic teachings, and men and women are both taught to dress and conduct themselves with dignity. The Quran teaches that:

"Say to believing men that they should lower their gaze and guard their chastity. And say to believing women that they should lower their gaze, guard their chastity, and not display their adornments except what is apparent." (Quran 24:30-31)

This verse highlights the concept of modesty, which is both a personal and societal value. Women in Islam are given the freedom to choose their attire while maintaining modesty, with many opting for the hijab or other forms of covering. It is important to note that modesty is not just a physical act but a reflection of the inner dignity, character, and values that are cherished in Islam.

In conclusion, the role of women in Islam is multifaceted and dynamic. Women are granted spiritual, social, intellectual, economic, and political rights that enable them to lead fulfilling and impactful lives. Through education and the practice of Islam, women continue to contribute significantly to society. Platforms like My Mufti App empower women by providing access to authentic Islamic knowledge, helping them understand and fulfill their rights and responsibilities.

Zakat is an abstract obligation from the Five Pillars of Islam: it signifies social justice, charity, and the balance of economics. Zakat itself is from the Arabic root that refers to purification and to growth, implying that when the right Zakat is given, it purifies one's wealth and creates an economic balance for society. It means that among the Muslims who are qualified in paying their Zakah, should take part in spending a certain portion of wealth in charity to ensure equal distribution of wealth and it is not hoarded.

It is about time that increased awareness and development of the internet have led to the emergence of websites such as My Mufti App for the convenience of the Muslims in accessing Zakat calculators, learning how to distribute Zakat, and more particularly, knowing how to fulfill this important duty in the correct way.

content.heading: 1. Zakat: Its Importance and Relevance
text: It is indeed compulsory charity forced by Allah to wipe out all forms of social injustices and inequalities. The Quran very explicitly says:
"Take from their wealth a charity with which you purify them and increase them, and invoke blessings upon them. Indeed, your invocations are reassurance for them." (Quran 9:103)

This ayah lays down an incontestable collective claim to Zakat; it purifies the wealth of the one giving it but can also add to the benefactor's public consequences. Compared to Zakat, which is an obligation (mandatory) for certain Muslims and has to be given to specific categories of persons, voluntary charity (Sadaqah) is zakat.

content.heading: 2. Who Has to Pay Zakat?
text: Zakat is compulsory upon every Muslim fulfilling the following conditions:

list: Adult Muslim: Zakat is obligatory on Muslims who have attained the age of majority.
Ownership of Wealth: One must own wealth in excess of the Nisab (minimum amount) after subtracting expenditure and debts.
Possession for One Lunar Year: The wealth should have been in one's possession for a complete Islamic (lunar) year.

text: The minimum threshold (Nisab) is set as follows:

list: 85 grams of gold or equivalent wealth.
595 grams of silver or equivalent wealth.

text: My Mufti App includes a simple Zakat calculator that assists Muslims in calculating their Nisab based on today's gold and silver prices.

content.heading: 3. How Much Zakat Must Be Paid?
text: The normal rate of Zakat is 2.5% of one's eligible assets. This includes:

list: Cash savings and bank accounts
Gold and silver (jewelry or bullion)
Investments (stocks, bonds, shares)
Business profits and assets
Agricultural produce and livestock (if applicable)
Rent from property

text: For example: if someone's savings exceed the Nisab for a lunar year by $10,000, they will have to pay Zakat at a rate of $250. The My Mufti App calculates Zakat obligations for users to ensure they don’t miss fulfilling this important duty.

content.heading: 4. Who Can Receive Zakat?
text: The Quran identifies eight categories eligible to receive Zakat (Quran 9:60):

list: The Poor (Al-Fuqara)
The Needy (Al-Masakin)
Administrators of Zakat
New Muslims and Those Whose Hearts Need Strengthening
Slaves and Captives
Debtors
In the Name of Allah (for Islamic causes)
Travelers in distress

text: My Mufti App gives advice on how to share Zakat appropriately, ensuring it reaches the rightful recipients according to Islamic principles.

content.heading: 5. Zakat's Spiritual and Social Gains
text: Zakat has profound spiritual and social benefits:

list: Spiritual Purification: Purifies wealth and heart from greed.
Economic Balance: Promotes equitable distribution of wealth.
Social Welfare: Helps meet the basic needs of the poor and reduces poverty.

text: "The shade of a believer on the Day of Resurrection will be his charity." (Tirmidhi)

content.heading: 6. Zakat vs. Sadaqah
text: Key differences:

list: Zakat is obligatory, while Sadaqah is voluntary.
Zakat is fixed at 2.5%; Sadaqah has no set amount.
Zakat must go to specific categories; Sadaqah can go to anyone.
Zakat is due only if one meets the Nisab; Sadaqah can be given anytime.

content.heading: 7. The Contemporary Use of Zakat
text: With digital tools and apps like My Mufti App, Muslims can now:

list: Compute Zakat based on up-to-date financial data
Give securely to verified Zakat causes
Track and manage payments
Learn about Zakat obligations

content.heading: 8. Zakat Common Misconceptions
text: Common misconceptions:

list: "Zakat is only for my family" – Not true; Zakat must follow Quranic categories.
"Zakat is only on income" – It applies to savings, gold, business assets, etc.
"Zakat can be given as services" – It must be monetary or material.
"Zakat is a tax" – It is an act of worship and purification, not a tax.

content.heading: Conclusion
text: Zakat is a foundational pillar of Islam that ensures justice, social balance, and personal purification. By paying Zakat, Muslims fulfill religious obligations and uplift those in need.
